required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Indwelling vs Immediate Removal of Foley Catheter After Robotic Assisted Laparoscopic Sacrocolpopexy: a Prospective Study
clinical_study.official_title: Indwelling vs Immediate Removal of Foley Catheter After Robotic Assisted Laparoscopic Sacrocolpopexy: a Prospective Study

brief_summary.textblock:
This is a prospective, comparative randomized study. Our study population includes women with pelvic organ prolapse undergoing a robotic assisted laparoscopic sacrocolpopexy.
The two groups will include the study group, who will have their Foley catheter removed before leaving the operating room, and the control group who will have an indwelling Foley catheter overnight. The two groups will be assigned according REDCap randomization system.

primary_outcome.description: Patients in the intervention group will have their Foley catheter removed up to 6 hours after discharge from the PCA. They will then have to undergo a voiding trial

secondary_outcome.description: All UTIs will be documented up to 30days post op.
Patient will fill in a questionnaire addressing different aspects of Foley satisfaction

arm_group.description: Patients will have Foley in place overnight after completion of surgery, which is currently standard of care at our institution.
Patients will have Foley catheter removed on postoperative day #0

intervention.description: Patients will have Foley catheter removed on postoperative day #0

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Age 19-75
- Pelvic organ prolapse requiring robotic assisted, laparoscopic sacrocolpopexy.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Intraoperative complications necessitating a post-operative Foley
- Cystotomy
- EBL >500mL
- Bowl injury
- Pre-operative urinary retention requiring an indwelling catheter

reference.citation: Geller EJ, Siddiqui NY, Wu JM, Visco AG. Short-term outcomes of robotic sacrocolpopexy compared with abdominal sacrocolpopexy. Obstet Gynecol. 2008 Dec;112(6):1201-6. doi: 10.1097/AOG.0b013e31818ce394.

Siddiqui NY, Geller EJ, Visco AG. Symptomatic and anatomic 1-year outcomes after robotic and abdominal sacrocolpopexy. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 2012 May;206(5):435.e1-5. doi: 10.1016/j.ajog.2012.01.035. Epub 2012 Feb 1.

Alessandri F, Mistrangelo E, Lijoi D, Ferrero S, Ragni N. A prospective, randomized trial comparing immediate versus delayed catheter removal following hysterectomy. Acta Obstet Gynecol Scand. 2006;85(6):716-20.

Ahmed MR, Sayed Ahmed WA, Atwa KA, Metwally L. Timing of urinary catheter removal after uncomplicated total abdominal hysterectomy: a prospective randomized trial. Eur J Obstet Gynecol Reprod Biol. 2014 May;176:60-3. doi: 10.1016/j.ejogrb.2014.02.038. Epub 2014 Mar 4.

Zhang P, Hu WL, Cheng B, Cheng L, Xiong XK, Zeng YJ. A systematic review and meta-analysis comparing immediate and delayed catheter removal following uncomplicated hysterectomy. Int Urogynecol J. 2015 May;26(5):665-74. doi: 10.1007/s00192-014-2561-0. Epub 2014 Nov 15. Review.

Summitt RL Jr, Stovall TG, Bran DF. Prospective comparison of indwelling bladder catheter drainage versus no catheter after vaginal hysterectomy. Am J Obstet Gynecol. 1994 Jun;170(6):1815-8; discussion 1818-21.

Dobbs SP, Jackson SR, Wilson AM, Maplethorpe RP, Hammond RH. A prospective, randomized trial comparing continuous bladder drainage with catheterization at abdominal hysterectomy. Br J Urol. 1997 Oct;80(4):554-6.
